messageBody:
I am trying to update (re: implement) a suite of tests that have
become old and no longer run. I am using ANT 1.6.2 and JUnit 3.8.1,
but I would be willing to use JUnit 4 if it would help. I am fairly
new to JUnit which is why I would like advice on which is the best way
I should proceed.

My original attempt to create test suites was to use XDoclet to
auto-generate 3 test suites based on category tags (unit, component,
system). For instance, UnitSuite would create a test suite that
contained calls to the suite methods of classes with the @... tag.

I would then run the <junit> ant task to execute the UnitSuite,
ComponentSuite and SystemSuite. This approach seemed fine until I
tried to implement the <junitreport> ant task and found that my
package structure was lost in the HTML report.

I have found a few discussions on how to remedy this issue, but they
seem rather complex to me. I believe I have three options as
follows. Any opinions/advice on any of them is greatly appreciated.

1.) Implement a custom test runner, listener and xsl style sheet to
format the output of the tests being run. The issue I am having with
this is how to break up the test suites and get the information out of
them.

2.) Break the categories up into directories so I can tell the <junit>
task to run all tests in a directory structure. The Unit directory
would contain the package structure of the classes under test and the
Component and System directories would use some custom directories for
describing the tests they contain. This is the option I am leaning
towards.

3.) Naming conventions for different test categories. I would not
like to impose such restrictions on the development team.

I would love to hear pros and cons for any of these options or if
there are any more I have missed.

Thanks for taking the time to read this message.

Patrick Gombola
